awd_abstract_narration:
Technical writing is a crucial skill for Science, Technology, Engineering, and Math (STEM) professionals.  To help develop and improve that skill, faculty in the Arkansas State University Department of Biological Sciences will collaborate with colleagues in the Department of English to design two STEM technical writing courses. The first one will be for undergraduate Biology majors. The second one will be for STEM and English graduate students.  The undergraduate writing course will be required of all students concurrent with Biology of the Cell Laboratory (BoCL). This is a lab class already required of all Biology majors.  It is usually taken in the sophomore year.  Graduate students who have successfully completed the graduate level course will receive further training in teaching. Each graduate student will be to work one-on-one with BoCL students. This project is an extension of a successful two-year pilot study pairing a technical writing course with Genetics Laboratory. Based on this pilot, the project team expects that BoCL students will improve their technical writing skills, their critical thinking ability, and their ease in reading and interpreting the scientific literature.  Further, the project team expects that university STEM and English graduate students will attain communication and teaching skills crucial to their future careers.  If successful, this program may serve as a model to increase all students' capabilities and progress in STEM. It has the potential to generalize to other institutions to enhance STEM education nationwide.

As is true at many universities, Arkansas State University undergraduate STEM students' formal writing training has consisted of English Composition.  This course crosses many genres but does not adequately prepare STEM students for the technical writing they face in their courses and research.  Thus, these students commonly enter graduate school lacking the science communication skills required for their future research careers.  Additionally, STEM faculty avoid including writing assignments in and out of the classroom, often because of faculty time constraints and the instructors' lack of formal training in writing instruction.  This grant will develop two STEM Technical Writing courses. One will be for undergraduate Biology majors (BoCL). The other will be for STEM and English graduate students (STW). These writing courses will be analyzed with respect to changes in the way educators work with students, particularly in writing. They will also be analyzed to determine whether writing and reading are concurrently improved through this cooperative effort. Additionally, this project will assess critical thinking. This project activity is based on the hypothesis that writing instruction can serve as a vehicle for increasing student understanding and thinking. To evaluate the success of this effort, students in both classes students will be assessed both pre- and post-semester. The assessment will evaluate the students' confidence in writing, knowledge of technical writing, and writing practices. The Critical Thinking Assessment Test will be used to assess student critical thinking. There are few existing, strong evaluation tools for STEM reading. Therefore, a test of critical reading will be developed and validated by project staff. It will be used to assess increases in critical reading in STW/BoCL students. This project could serve as a model for other institutions to enhance STEM education and communication nationwide.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Faculty around the country bemoan the cognitive and communication skills of undergraduate students. Because of large classes, STEM faculty struggle to integrate writing assignments in their class and give adequate feedback with enough iterations for students to improve their writing skills. Further, many faculty lack formal training in writing instruction. Yet, communication (including written) is one of the top skills employers seek. The general goal of the project was to change the way we teach students to understand science so that they become science-literate citizens with stronger skills in writing, but also reading, understanding, and critical thinking.

To that end, the project team––a combination of faculty from the Biology and English departments at Arkansas State University––developed two STEM technical writing courses, one for Biology undergraduate students and another for STEM and Humanities graduate students. We coordinated the undergraduate-level writing course with a laboratory course (Biology of the Cell), required for all Biology majors. The writing course was optional so that we could compare improvements between students who took this course and those who did not. In addition, we recruited two graduate students (one from STEM and another from Humanities) as dedicated writing teaching assistants (WTAs) to provide feedback on three iterative reports students wrote as part of the laboratory course. These WTAs were trained either through the graduate-level writing course or through a summer workshop. Reports were divided into three groups: one graded by the STEM WTA, another graded by the Humanities WTA, and the last graded by both WTAs. By emphasizing genre awareness (ability to recognize and use characteristics of various types of texts), providing conceptual tools to unpack scientific text, and giving personalized feedback in an iterative fashion, our setup was meant to help students improve their skills and confidence in writing, critical thinking, and critical reading of the scientific literature. We predicted that the writing course alone would increase students’ skills and confidence and we predicted that the combination of WTAs from different disciplines would further improve students’ skills and confidence. To determine if these predictions would be supported, we not only analyzed the progress in their writing between the first and last reports, but we also administered a perception survey and a critical thinking assessment test at the beginning and end of each semester from fall 2019 to fall 2023––although some semesters could not be used in our analyses because of biases resulting from the COVID19 pandemic. 

Overall, critical thinking and scientific writing improved over the course of a semester. However, the results were not consistent for us to attribute these improvements to the writing course or the presence of one or both WTAs. Having a WTA helped students understand scientific literature and increase their confidence and skills in writing. Furthermore, students who had both WTAs did better on the critical thinking test than those who had only one WTA. Yet, the group graded by both WTAs only marginally outperformed the other two groups in improving writing skills. Surprisingly, students who attended the writing course did not see their writing skills improve. Although our results were not always consistent and we could not always attribute the improvement in writing and critical thinking skills to the writing course or to the presence of WTAs, our results suggest that repeated exposure to writing helped students improve their skills and boost their confidence and comfort in writing, reading, and critical thinking. These results of boosted confidence are an important step toward retention and success of STEM students in our region, the Delta region of Arkansas, where school districts are isolated, underfunded, and struggle with low performance on standardized and state tests.

This project also provided professional development to four WTAs who all reported that this experience made them more effective communicators, writers, and educators. One of them is now a visiting assistant professor in Georgia, another is pursuing a PhD in Tennessee and his dissertation research is in part inspired by this project, a third one is a communication representative for a private company, and the last is on track to finish his Masters degree at Arkansas State University. Fourteen students took the graduate class reporting on the benefits of the course, including one who uses tools from the course in their current job as a high school teacher. Fifty took the undergraduate writing course, which the Department of English will continue to offer.  

We presented the project and its results at a national conference (although attended by internationals as well) in which several individuals from graduate teaching assistants to post-doctoral researchers and professors excitedly shared wanting to implement at least parts of our ideas at their institutions. We hope that this excitement will translate to a more literate STEM workforce nationwide.
